scope="row" | | | |- ! scope="row" | | | |- ! scope="row" | | | |- ! scope="row" | | | |} ===All-Star Game selections=== The National Hockey League All-Star Game is a mid-season exhibition game held annually between many of the top players of each season. Sixty-four All-Star Games have been held since 1947, with at least one player chosen to represent the Rangers in each year. The All-Star Game has not been held in various years: 1979 and 1987 due to the 1979 Challenge Cup and Rendez- vous '87 series between the NHL and the Soviet national team, respectively; 1995, 2005 and 2013 as a result of labor stoppages; and 2006, 2010 and 2014 due to the Winter Olympic Games. The Rangers have hosted two of the games. The 26th and 45th took place at Madison Square Garden. * Selected by fan vote * All-Star Game Most Valuable Player2014–15 NHL Official Guide & Record Book, p. 234 {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+New York Rangers players and coaches selected to the All-Star Game2014–15 New York Rangers Media Guide, p.347–48 |- !scope="col" | Game !scope="col" | Year !scope="col" | Name !scope="col" | Position !scope="col" class="unsortable"| References |- !scope="row" rowspan="3" | |rowspan="3" |1947 | | |rowspan="3" | |- | | |- | | |- !scope="row" rowspan="3" | |rowspan="3" |1948 | | |rowspan="3" | |- | | |- | | |- !scope="row" rowspan="5" | |rowspan="5" |1949 | | |rowspan="5" | |- | | |- | | |- | | |- | | |- ! scope="row"| 60th |2015 | | | |- ! scope="row"| 61st |2016 | | | |- ! scope="row" | 62nd |2017 | | | |- ! scope="row" | 63rd |2018 | | | |- ! scope="row" | 64th |2019 | | | |- ! scope="row" rowspan=2| 65th |rowspan=2|2020 | (Replaced Panarin) | |rowspan=2| |- | (Did not play) | |} ===All-Star benefit games=== Prior to the institution of the National Hockey League All-Star Game the league held three different benefit games featuring teams of all-stars. The first was the Ace Bailey Benefit Game, held in 1934, after a violent collision with Eddie Shore of the Boston Bruins left Ace Bailey of the Toronto Maple Leafs hospitalized and unable to continue his playing career. In 1937 the Howie Morenz Memorial Game was held to raise money for the family of Howie Morenz of the Montreal Canadiens who died from complications after being admitted to the hospital for a broken leg. The Babe Siebert Memorial Game was held in 1939 to raise funds for the family of the Canadiens' Babe Siebert who drowned shortly after he retired from playing. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+New York Rangers players and coaches selected to All-Star benefit games |- !scope="col" | Game !scope="col" | Year !scope="col" | Name !scope="col" | Position !scope="col" class="unsortable"| References |- !scope="row" rowspan="3"| |rowspan="3"|1934 | | |rowspan="3"| |- | | |- | | |- !scope="row" rowspan="2"| |rowspan="2"|1937 | | |rowspan="2"| |- | | |- !scope="row" rowspan="2"| |rowspan="2"|1939 | | |rowspan="2"| |- | | |} ===All-Star Game replacement events=== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+New York Rangers players and coaches selected to All-Star Game replacement events |- !scope="col" | Event !scope="col" | Year !scope="col" | Name !scope="col" | Position !scope="col" class="unsortable"| References |- !scope="row" rowspan="3"| |rowspan="3"|1979 | (Did not play) | |rowspan="3"| |- | | |- | | |- !scope="row" | |1987 | | | |} ==Career achievements== ===Hockey Hall of Fame=== The following is a list of New York Rangers who have been enshrined in the Hockey Hall of Fame.2014–15 New York Rangers Media Guide, p.345 {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+New York Rangers inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame ! scope="row" | |Player |1980 |1952–1953, 1954–1963 |, retrieved June 22, 2015 |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2019 |1992–1995 | |} ===Foster Hewitt Memorial Award=== Three members of the Rangers organization have been honored with the Foster Hewitt Memorial Award. The award is presented by the Hockey Hall of Fame to members of the radio and television industry who make outstanding contributions to their profession and the game of ice hockey during their broadcasting career. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Members of the New York Rangers honored with the Foster Hewitt Memorial Award ! scope="col" |Individual ! scope="col" |Year honored ! scope="col" |Years with Rangers as broadcaster ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" | |2009 |1983–1984, 1986–2006 | |- ! scope="row" | |2005 |1974–2003 | |- ! scope="row" | |2016 |1984–present | |} ===Lester Patrick Trophy=== The Lester Patrick Trophy has been presented by the National Hockey League and USA Hockey since 1966 to honor a recipient's contribution to ice hockey in the United States. This list includes all personnel who have ever been employed by the New York Rangers in any capacity and have also received the Lester Patrick Trophy. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Members of the New York Rangers honored with the Lester Patrick Trophy2014–15 New York Rangers Media Guide, p.344 ! scope="row" | |2000 |1989–1997 | |- ! scope="row" | |2008 |1989–2003 | |- ! scope="row" | |2015 |1998–2000 | |- ! scope="row" | |2007 |1981, 1983–1993 | |- ! scope="row" | |2013 |1991–1993 | |} ===Retired numbers=== The New York Rangers have retired eight of their jersey numbers. Also out of circulation is the number 99 which was retired league-wide for Wayne Gretzky on February 6, 2000. Gretzky played the final three seasons of his 20-year NHL career with the Rangers and was the only Rangers player who ever wore the number 99 prior to its retirement. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+New York Rangers retired numbers ! scope="col" |Number ! scope="col" |Player ! scope="col" |Position ! scope="col" |Years with Rangers as a player ! scope="col" |Date of retirement ceremony ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" |1 | | |1965–1975 |March 15, 1989 |2014–15 New York Rangers Media Guide, p.333 |- ! scope="row" |2 | | |1987–2004 |January 24, 2008 |2014–15 New York Rangers Media Guide, p.335 |- ! scope="row" |3 | | |1952–1969 |February 22, 2009 |2014–15 New York Rangers Media Guide, p.336 |- ! scope="row" |7 | | |1960–1977 |October 14, 1979 | |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2"|9 | | |1952–1964 |February 22, 2009 | |- | | |1991–2001 |February 3, 2009 | |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2"|11 | | |1961–1974 |December 2, 2018 | |- | | |1991–1997, 2000–2004 |January 12, 2006 |2014–15 New York Rangers Media Guide, p.334 |- ! scope="row" |19 | | |1960–1975 |February 25, 2018 | |- ! scope="row" |35 | | |1989–2003 |February 4, 2004 | |} ==Team awards== ===John Halligan Good Guy Award=== The John Halligan Good Guy Award is an annual award which "recognizes a player for their cooperation with the media throughout the season." It was renamed for longtime Rangers public relations director John Halligan after Halligan's death on January 20, 2010. {| class="wikitable" ! scope="col" style="width:5em"|Season ! scope="col" style="width:15em"|Winner |- ! It has not been awarded since the New York Rangers Fan Club suspended operations in 2010. {| class="wikitable" ! scope="col" style="width:5em"|Season ! scope="col" style="width:15em"|Winner |- ! scope="row"| 1994–95 | Adam Graves |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2"| 1995–96 | Adam Graves |- | Glenn Healy |- ! scope="row"| 1996–97 | Adam Graves |- ! scope="row"| 1997–98 | Adam Graves |- ! scope="row"| 1998–99 | Adam Graves |} {| class="wikitable" ! scope="col" style="width:5em"|Season ! scope="col" style="width:15em"|Winner |- ! scope="row"| 1999–00 | Adam Graves |- ! scope="row"| 2000–01 | Adam Graves |- ! scope="row"| 2001–02 | Brian Leetch |- ! scope="row"| 2002–03 | Brian Leetch |- ! scope="row"| 2003–04 | Mark Messier |- ! scope="row"| 2005–06 | Henrik Lundqvist |} {| class="wikitable" ! scope="col" style="width:5em"|Season ! scope="col" style="width:15em"|Winner |- ! scope="row"| 2006–07 | Brendan Shanahan |- ! scope="row"| 2007–08 | Brendan Shanahan |- ! scope="row"| 2008–09 | Henrik Lundqvist |- ! scope="row"| 2009–10 | Erik Christensen |} ==="Crumb Bum" Award=== The "Crumb Bum" Award is given to a member of the Rangers organization in recognition for service to New York youngsters.
